awd_titl_txt: Two-Dimensional Pre-Assembled Multi-Scale Brownian Soft Matter
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
Some pure materials are highly uniform and have essentially the same structure and properties from very small to very large length scales. However, other materials, including biological tissues, have different structures and properties at different length scales from microscopic to macroscopic; these are 'multi-scale' materials. One of the most important current challenges in physical science involves developing rules that describe increasingly complex multi-scale materials which begin to approach the extremely high level of complexity found in biology. This project focuses on creating and studying the behavior of highly contollable synthetic multi-scale materials that contain moving shape-designed particulate components dispersed in a liquid. Optical lithography, which is the key technology for mass-producing computer chips, enables the top-down production of human-designed, pre-configured, multi-scale materials composed of mobile tile-like particles that have interesting shapes and arrangements at different length scales in two dimensions. Beyond revealing physical rules that govern the dynamics and structures of mobile constituents and coupling between different length scales in such multi-scale materials using optical microscopy, this project benefits K-12 students, including underrepresented minority students, in the Los Angeles area by introducing them to the basic concepts of lithography through age-appropriate educational modules that are deployed in conjunction with educators-in-training at UCLA's Center X.

Technical Abstract:
The recent advent of lithographically pre-assembled monolayers of mobile shape-designed colloidal tiles, made using optical stepper lithography, provides a new and powerful experimental route for making two-dimensional dynamic systems having controllable multi-scale complexity. This project takes advantage of lithographically pre-assembled monolayers to explore both equilibrium and non-equilibrium multi-scale materials, including quasi-crystals and hierarchical crystals-of-crystals, that have controlled symmetries and topologies spanning a wide range of length scales. Time-lapse optical video microscopy experiments of these systems yield spatio-temporal kinetics and dynamics down to the tile scale, thereby yielding measurements of the fluctuations and evolution of shape-designed monolayer systems both as a consequence of entropic Brownian excitations and also as a consequence of active driving. From particle tracking analysis of these videos, quantitative insight into multi-scale complex systems of crowded shapes  serves as a starting point for understanding more complex forms of active and biological matter.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
While most people are aware that the effective brains and memory in their electronic devices are chips, relatively few are aware that the vast majority of these chips are made using optical processes involving stepper lithography systems, or 'steppers'. Such optical steppers are the main patterning machines that are presently being used in semiconductor fabrication facilities to mass-produce tiny electronic circuits over large areas of wafers down to incredibly small nanoscale dimensions with amazingly low defects. In this project, we have repurposed optical stepper technology and have used it to fabricate and study new kinds of synthetic materials that are composed of tiny, mobile, off-chip, shape-designed structures. As a starting point, we have focused on creating two-dimensional systems of microscopic plate-like particles, which are effectively tiny tiles, that can be released off a chip into a liquid. Over many decades, physical scientists have been interested in entropy and how it relates to the random motion of microscopic particles in liquids, such as pollen grains in water studied by Brown in the 1800s using optical microscopy, revealing an entropic phenomenon that is now called Brownian motion. However, until very recently when steppers have appeared, scientists previously have lacked experimental methods for producing highly controlled dense systems of microscopic particles that have customized human-designed shapes and that also are pre-configured in customized human-designed patterns. Key scientific questions about entropy and fluctuations of mobile microscale particles, which have a wide variety of different shapes, at high densities still remain, both in two dimensions and also in three dimensions. These questions can be addressed more readily if customized, highly controlled systems of particles with low defects could be created.

In this project, we have opened the door to the exciting prospect of creating highly complex, human-designed, organized systems of microscopic particles that are off-chip and move in a liquid through entropic Brownian motion. In particular, we have designed, fabricated, and studied a never-before-seen fluctuating heptatic (7-fold symmetric) liquid quasi-crystal (LQC), and, in separate experiments, we have also created self-integral chain-like configurations of lock-and-key linkage-particles to form fluctuating chains that resemble polymers. We call such chains polylithomers, where a lithomer is a shape-designed lithographic colloidal monomer (i.e. an individual building block of a polymer). In effect, we have demonstrated in the lab that top-down methods of design and production of off-chip custom-shape building blocks can be achieved and that these building blocks can be initially configured at high densities to form new, exquisite, complex, human-designed, fluctuating, equilibrium phases of matter and non-equilibrium states of matter that have never previously existed. In other words, we have imagined intricate new forms of off-chip complex dynamic matter, such as the fluctuating heptatic LQC, and we have developed and demonstrated experimental methods for designing and producing such forms of matter over large regions with few defects using an optical stepper. Moreover, we have developed computer simulations that show how differences in geometrically designed bonds between lock-and-key lithomers alter the average properties of polylithomer chains. 

We expect that our research into this emerging area of materials science will have a high impact intellectually and will spark many future experiments that reveal other new forms of matter. Continuing research based on the results of this project will further enhance our scientific understanding of entropy and its implications in condensed matter systems. In terms of broader impacts, we anticipate that a wide range of new types of condensed matter and potentially also related devices having unusual properties will be made and studied by the scientific and engineering communities as a result of our work. Also, our outreach, in conjunction with UCLA's California NanoSystems Institute, has educated K-12 teachers in Los Angeles about the marvels of modern lithographic methods, including optical stepper lithography for the benefit of many children, including underrepresented children. In addition, this project has directly benefited the graduate education of UCLA graduate PhD students. Overall, this project has led to many positive impacts ranging from intellectual to societal.
